repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body: @dcousens I couldn't see any existing usage of min/max in the code, so I just kept it simple here. Not sure it's important for VERIFY checks anyway, but I think it's pretty common for the compiler to eliminate any branch here (at least when optimizations are enabled).

MAX is not standard C afaik? we can define it ourselves, of course.

I don't care about performance inside VERIFY. It should be correct, and readable. Usin MAX/MIN helps there, but I think we should do perhaps introduce those independently in another PR if we want it.
@sipa sure,  I see no reason to hold up the PR for it.  Just wanted to flag it.

comments.body:
`r->magnitude = MAX(a->magnitude, r->magnitude)`

Is clearer IMHO, given the short as hell variable names.
The compiler probably already makes the branchless optimization though,  but conceptually it could be faster too.
